document.title: English Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools March 2024

6B315AB156094F5A88367C6119379128.description:
Demonstrate ethical and responsible use of all sources, including the Internet, Artificial
Intelligence (AI), and new technologies, as they develop.

19426ED93C394539ABCBF5B0E4F0586E.description:
Define the meaning and consequences of plagiarism and follow ethical and legal guidelines
for gathering and using information.

0D4812FC94924ABC9F97041226FA8D98.description:
Cite primary and secondary sources for quoted and paraphrased ideas using a standard
method of documentation such as the Modern Language Association (MLA) or American
Psychological Association (APA).

BE8934F02F514B538C2F0649DCEA3617.description: Create research products aligned with the demands of the reading and writing standards.

D98BCBA8AB1248068F5EB88918E11120.description: Synthesize multiple streams of evidence to support claims and acknowledge counterclaims.

8112F84EB1BC4C6F97562EA01009C88A.description:
Objectively evaluate primary and secondary sources for their credibility, reliability,
accuracy, usefulness, and limitations. That includes identifying their main and supporting
ideas, points of view, conflicting information, and any misconceptions or biases.

31FA3D85E27C4EDEAED897364D36B6E5.description: Gather and organize information from various sources.

41F7068A28BC49DCA844F653F3461CF0.description:
Formulate and revise questions about a research topic broadening or narrowing the inquiry
as necessary.

B9114DCB26BB4A7C9DD48D101C9A905C.description:
The student will conduct research and read a series of conceptually related texts on
selected topics to build knowledge on grade-eleven content, texts, and areas prompted by
student interest.Â

C6C05741ECA544709F9FDE351A6F95BE.description:
Analyze, compare, and contrast visual and verbal media messages for content (e.g., word
choice and choice of information), intent (e.g., persuasive techniques), impact (e.g., public
opinion trends), and effectiveness (e.g., effect on the audience).

AB889D4D27AF44B187C8D597C7D3A11E.description: Analyze and critique how media reach the targeted audience for specific purposes

09389A0C548448B8A441705B6E2A5C11.description:
Analyze the sources and viewpoint(s) of publications including advertisements, editorials,
blogs, and websites.

1EE3439DA5754A71942319FB84E9E3AD.description:
Ethically, purposefully, and strategically incorporate multimodal tools including the
Internet and varying technology.

7C73A67380BD447896833BED61A2D0EC.description:
Monitor, organize, analyze, and synthesize multiple streams of simultaneous information to
create a summary or formulate a position.

FEA56EBB40594EAA9B8C74B8F67F7D68.description:
Demonstrate understanding of multimodal literacy by identifying and evaluating elements
such as authorship, format, audience, content, and purpose.

49966B22603D4782BA93A6C9188744AB.description:
Create, publish, and deliver multimodal presentations and pieces aimed at a variety of
audiences and with different purposes, incorporating spoken or written components.

A6C0190A4AF04151BC7B19719A82A0BA.description:
Evaluating the content and effectiveness of presentations; that includes the introduction,
organization, strengths/weaknesses in evidence and reasoning, and conclusion.Â

2A121D9413784226B52EEBFFD803AE82.description:
Anticipating and addressing alternative or opposing perspectives and counterclaims
using counter arguments and rebuttals, as appropriate.Â

7EE363FADA53488C8943808971C6BA66.description:
Utilizing rhetorical techniques (e.g., ethos, pathos, and logos), repetition, and figurative
language to deliver a message.

7CD84692E33A4079915A1A5EE470F186.description:
Using a variety of active listening and speaking strategies, with awareness of intent and
impact of verbal and nonverbal cues.

103F62017971438A8233A828369DAFC9.description: Choosing diction and tone appropriate to the topic, audience, and purpose.

840EB09F87A942059DB2847B58467C71.description:
Selecting the modes and purposes for presentations and synthesizing multiple streams
of information.

0936FA9BE0C647FEA50AF1B304EB4A28.description: Report orally on a topic or text or present an opinion. This includes:

93B3141AE96740B19361584C24604E8E.description:
Using reflection to evaluate one's own role in the group process in small-group
activities.

26C09410A7074A4CA7381EFF6CA327FF.description: Assessing, evaluating critically, and using information accurately to fulfill a task.

498D5AF169C04973959EDBDDD83901D3.description: Summarizing points of agreement and disagreement.

F3625A36F64A4347AD25D7D8235FCA3B.description: Responding thoughtfully and tactfully with evidence to diverse perspectives.

B0FFC2BF56BE43269B0C267450527038.description:
Demonstrating the ability to work effectively by coming to a consensus, exercising
flexibility, making necessary compromises, and presenting alternate views.

A82B461209E64A8CBF91946FCB4B96DC.description:
Applying a variety of strategies to listen actively and speak purposefully and
respectfully.

3A031F99D72B4185905115F96BA0B679.description:
Facilitate and contribute to a range of sustained collaborative discussions with diverse
partners on grade eleven topics and texts. This includes:

D18500559C7842129315C96607981BE6.description:
The student will develop effective oral communication and collaboration skills to build
a community of learners that process, understand, and interpret content together.

15C1EA82FD6B4825B3855B951A62978F.description: Spell correctly, consulting reference materials to check as needed.

C2D263EB20364E63A1C41EA6EAB9F6F4.description:
Write and edit work so that it conforms to the guidelines in style manual, such as that of the
Modern Language Association (MLA) or the American Psychological Association (APA).Â

D335AD8B265C4396A55EA5654A7875EF.description: Use commas, semi-colons, and colons correctly in complex sentences in writing.Â

6F0D69EC8E7B4999866CCC21851FD1BE.description:
Differentiate and apply active and passive voice to convey a desired effect in speaking and
writing.

A8AFF8B730C44F8EA544732CB3612185.description: Use complex sentence structure to infuse sentence variety in writing.

22DE6A5B0C4749BE89D4AD821B1D9CB2.description: Use verbal phrases to achieve sentence conciseness and variety in speaking and writing.Â

0909850D722E4E4FB22EFD96836D2530.description:
The student will use the conventions of Standard English when speaking and writing,
differentiating between contexts that call for formal English and situations where informal
discourse is more appropriate.

9476EC60C82E4E2E8B5A24399DE9C833.description:
Write and revise to a standard acceptable both in the workplace and in post-secondary
education.

C1DA2887BC9D433B96D7A83F58E6C2A8.description:
Edit writing for appropriate conventions, style, and language (See Language Usage for
grade level expectations).

482B7053CF2D4BAFA8C84792E10B44E2.description:
Use peer- and self-evaluation to edit writing for clarity and quality of information,
addressing strengths and making suggestions regarding how writing might be improved.

B11E2CF0B8CF4C15814268B01FCA5BCF.description: Revise writing for clarity of content, accuracy, and depth of information.

8EFFA7259F1240EB9622840FB8E496EB.description: Elaborating ideas clearly through purposeful and precise word choice.Â

C67CD57C004647DA8CA505E189E5EC15.description:
Applying varied transitions and sentence structures to connect ideas within and
across paragraphs.

D367C77632774F96BEA676274DEF8841.description:
Effectively contextualizing evidence from sources with proper introduction and
thorough explanation.

9CE33D5BDFD94073A3DC894D820C766B.description:
Organizing claims, counterclaims, and evidence in a sustained and logical sequence
to exhibit unity.

2BB9160058A148FBB1C9E078088AA9DC.description:
Composing a thesis statement that clearly communicates the writerâs position or
assertion.

0217DC1D5C4F4298A7078DCF61A5D412.description:
Plan and organize writing to address a specific audience and purpose using the writing
process (planning, drafting, revising, editing). This includes:Â

500CAB19162E4ADB9EF1795309562813.description:
Choose appropriate modes and blend multiple forms of writing by routinely engaging in the
production of shorter and longer pieces that adapt writing content, technique, and voice for
a range of audiences, purposes, and tasks (e.g. summaries, reflections, descriptions,
critiques, letters, poetry, narratives, etc.).

9BCE993BA1834BE2A113178FCC3384BF.description:
Write to describe personal qualifications for potential occupational or educational
opportunities, producing clear and coherent writing in which the development,
organization, and style match the intended audience and purpose of the workplace and/or
post-secondary education and language in informal and formal contexts.

6333886B53004CFEB92C47F6251AEDC0.description:
Organize claims, counterclaims, and evidence in a sustained and logical sequence that
explains how the credible evidence supports well-defined points of view.

343D00E534B74F31A1D5017DC5C6A9A5.description: Examine and evaluate processes and/or problems to propose solutions.

E2D1FACA4CA14675A7E5CD96D5797D07.description:
Interpret and investigate evidence from various sources and texts to draw reasonable
conclusions that support the writerâs position or assertion.

331EB2B38D7A4C66BD702EDA61D570DD.description: Develop a thesis that demonstrates knowledgeable judgments.

B58F0E046268448CAC972BCB1917B241.description:
Provide a concluding section that follows from the information or explanation
presented.Â

2C47215DA5E74FA49176AA3B99857A45.description:
Develop the topic through sustained use of the most significant and relevant facts,
concrete details, quotations, or other information from multiple authoritative sources
appropriate to the audienceâs knowledge.

CFCC266B05274FEBB4D53CDF0292E41B.description: Adopt an organizational structure that clarifies relationships among ideas and concepts.

D32B5C4DE0D14637B817196D31270983.description:
Introduce a topic clearly by providing context, presenting well-defined theses, and
previewing what follows.

3145491CB59E4FA99F858064DEC2FEDA.description:
The student will write in a variety of forms for diverse audiences and purposes linked
to grade eleven content and text with an emphasis on argumentative and analytical writing.Â

96117EDBA2274240AF234225C8B91EA8.description: Compare and contrast informational and technical texts for intent, content, and clarity.

588F4D4BFFC2494A9E85A569BF2BDE9A.description:
Analyze information within and between paired passages for similar and conflicting ideas
and how authors reach similar or different conclusions.

B2798AB52F244BF08AD39E96A7BE6FAE.description:
Recognize and analyze the authorâs purpose and impact of ambiguity, contradiction,
paradox, oxymoron, irony, sarcasm, overstatement, and understatement in informational
texts.

EA7F7E65A0464D81829B9D3CB028CCAC.description:
Analyze and interpret the key terms (e.g., content-specific words and phrases, technical
terminology) and ideas of historical, scientific, technical, and employment texts to clarify
concepts.Â

12EAB6FFBE354803BC695F9ADB4E13A4.description:
Examine how textual elements and organizational patterns contribute to meaning and the
authorâs purpose.

386AB779D30A4CE9AF19E37C439442D0.description:
Evaluate the relevance and quality of an authorâs premises, claims, counterclaims, and
evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information.

E7108CDE95C640D7A8776864E85F3291.description:
Analyze the hypotheses, data, analysis, and/or conclusions in informational, historical,
scientific, or technical texts, verifying the data when possible and corroborating or
challenging conclusions with other sources of information.Â

20355EB7C207422899B8D25268957ED3.description:
Interpret and complete an application for employment or college admission, and summarize
the intent, main ideas, and purpose of the workplace or technical documents.

F9692376AF5142E1A29D3F652EB8FC45.description:
The student will use textual evidence to demonstrate comprehension and build
knowledge from grade-level complex informational texts read.

0A7167DA69F84BD6B7A929DDAB6E6815.description:
Analyze how authorsâ attitudes, viewpoints, and beliefs reflect larger historical, social, or
cultural contexts.

32D1FB72F95B43B399E0622B12C57755.description:
Relate themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or
religious works to contemporary stories, poems, or drama.

6B92CC5D167B4F1AA7CA266AE5058DE9.description:
Explain the influence of the historical and cultural context on form, style, and point of view
of texts that represent diverse voices and perspectives.

0DC8B42311B545F48373BCCC73CC11C3.description:
Analyze the use of satire, sarcasm, irony, and understatement to differentiate between what
is directly stated and what is implied.

DD3A59917A5E4C568889EBBDE532F5C5.description:
Critique how authors use key literary devices (e.g., imagery, personification, symbolism) to
contribute to the meaning of a text, including its character development, theme, conflict,
and archetypes.

6AE2DCF600764957B572EA89FD92CA8D.description:
Evaluate how authors use specific word choices, syntax, tone, and voice to convey the
authorâs intent and viewpoint.Â

D2D36B394C974973B2D92F76B5CDF761.description:
Interpret and analyze how the sound and imagery of poetry support the subject, mood,
form, and theme and appeal to the readerâs senses.Â

6AB55A02402C417EA7CACDE9D9268388.description:
Analyze and evaluate how dramatic conventions (e.g., soliloquy, aside, narration, direct
address to the audience) contribute to the theme and effect of plays from various cultures.Â

E81699FFA66B4268ACB455B9DCA73411.description: Analyze how characters are revealed through particular lines of dialogue or events.

8AAF109AEA0E4F4FA6C640D87CBA724A.description:
Describe how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure
of a text and contributes to the development of the setting and plot.Â

0A38C22387EB4332B09E9EBA5B79C5DF.description:
Analyze the development of universal themes (e.g., loss of innocence, coming of age,
relationship with nature) prevalent in American literature (e.g., short stories, poems, plays,
novels, essays, and literary nonfiction) of different eras.

74E76C26BDB84CA0AA69F731D3B1602B.description:
The student will use textual evidence to demonstrate comprehension and build
knowledge from a variety of grade-level complex literary texts read to include literary
nonfiction (including world, British, and American literature), narratives, poetry, and
drama, with an emphasis on American literature.Â

B620E8886FE540B78DDDD0703D1BEFE3.description:
Use newly learned words and phrases in multiple contexts, including in studentsâ
discussions and speaking and writing activities.

00D81889DB8E4353924ADA6461359E7F.description:
Explain the meaning of figurative language and literary and classical allusions and analyze
their role in texts.

787B311825DB42E99D327423FA48C5EF.description: Explain and analyze idiomatic language in context.

039B679BF72F4D728872FB321181DCC3.description:
Analyze the nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations (e.g., clever,
cunning, brainy).Â

22089BE687D74845B3135AD3825F238F.description:
Use structural analysis of roots, affixes, and etymology to understand the meanings of
unfamiliar and complex words.Â

587F31EBCC834157A3028BF71506A1F0.description: Use context and sentence structure to clarify the meanings of words and phrases.

EBA851CB58C24EF4AE5BCFCF56B50394.description:
Develop and accurately use general academic and content-specific vocabulary through
reading, discussing, and writing about grade-level texts and topics.

17527E22C7E146619BEBAB998E16D107.description:
The student will systematically build vocabulary and word knowledge based on grade
eleven content and texts.

0982F31DA9D048AEAEE2D9044567018D.description:
Use reading strategies as needed to aid and monitor comprehension when encountering
challenging sections of text. These sense-making strategies attend to text structure,
common organizational structures, summarizing, asking questions of the text, and others
(Reading Strategies, 3-12).Â

661E4AC8749A4DA68FA29F9A1895A759.description:
Regularly engage in reading a series of conceptually related texts organized around topics
of study to build knowledge and vocabulary (These texts should be at a range of
complexity levels so students can read the texts independently, with peers, or with modest
support.). Use this background knowledge as context for new learning (Deep Reading on
Topics to Build Knowledge and Vocabulary, K-12).Â

3BD05AA6948047669129361600891657.description:
When responding to text through discussions and/or writing, draw several pieces of
evidence from grade-level complex texts to support claims, conclusions, and inferences,Â including quoting or paraphrasing from texts accurately and tracing where relevant
evidence is located (Textual Evidence, K-12).V

3A3276606391416CBE8355B3563FA2C4.description:
Proficiently read and comprehend a variety of literary and informational texts that exhibit
complexity at the lower range of the grades 11-12 band to generate and respond logically to
literal, inferential, evaluative, synthesizing, and critical thinking questions (See the
Quantitative and Qualitative Analysis charts for determining complexity in the Appendix.)
(Text Complexity, 2-12).

210419951B4B41C3A6DBD1FB22751E07.description:
Read a variety of grade-level complex texts with accuracy, automaticity, appropriate rate,
and meaningful expression in successive readings to support comprehension. Monitor
while reading to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, as necessary
(Reading Fluency, K-12).

C142249C7D7F45329E69081C04A7C802.description:
The student will build knowledge and comprehension skills from reading a range of
challenging, content-rich texts. This includes fluently reading and gathering evidence from
grade-level complex texts, reading widely on topics to gain purposeful knowledge and
vocabulary, and using reading strategies when comprehension breaks down.Â

9EDB765A548B4BEF82456C6057AEA07F.description: Developing Skilled Readers and Building Reading StaminaÂ
